awd_titl_txt: Evaluating the Influence of Ecoroof Surfaces on Indoor Air Quality
awd_abstract_narration:
1605843 
Starry, Olyssa

Americans spend 90% of their time in buildings, resulting in exposures to air pollution being largely dictated by indoor air quality. One key determinant of indoor air quality is ventilation of indoor spaces with outside air. Increased rates of building ventilation have been correlated with improved occupant health, satisfaction, and productivity. However, improved indoor air quality, from increased ventilation, is ultimately contingent on the quality of outdoor air. Ecoroofs are an increasingly popular strategy for improving building sustainability that result in vegetated building surfaces that may be in close proximity to a building?s outdoor air supply (often rooftop). While air quality models indicate that ecoroofs may remove substantial quantities of air pollutants from urban atmospheres, no empirical studies are known that investigate how an ecoroof may affect the indoor air quality of the same building. Urban air quality studies of ecoroofs typically consider only deposition of air pollutants, however, there is precedence for vegetation to emit volatile compounds that may degrade indoor air quality or participate in secondary chemistries which results in the formation of irritating or harmful air pollutants. Therefore, there is a need to critically and holistically evaluate source, sink, and transformations of air pollutants at vegetated ecoroof surfaces. Examining how ecoroofs may impact indoor air quality is critical for developing more sustainable building designs and for identifying synergistic opportunities to enhance the sustainability of the urban environment. 

This research will investigate the effects of ecoroofs on indoor air quality with a holistic approach that addresses two fundamental, yet interrelated research questions: 1) How does the design of a building rooftop affect deposition, processing, and emissions of air pollutants? and 2) How might ecoroofs affect indoor air quality? This project will address these questions with a combination of extensive and innovative data collection that integrates ecology, biology, and building science approaches. Specific investigations will include a broad field survey of 48 roof surfaces in Portland, OR, an intensive air quality monitoring study at a commercial facility with a dual ecoroof/white membrane roof, and bench-scale laboratory investigations. Field measurements and laboratory parameterizations will be used in statistical models and material balances to explain relationships between the urban environment, ecoroofs, and indoor air quality. This project will provide data that leads to an improved understanding of ecoroof-indoor air quality interactions. The data, parameterizations, and models from this project will inform building sustainability practices by enabling indoor air quality impacts to be integrated into ecoroof and urban green-surface design. Study outcomes will help identify opportunities to improve indoor air quality and reduce human exposure to air pollutants. The project will work closely with the City of Portland and the local Greenroof Information Thinktank (GRIT) to engage the community in this work and disseminate results to the public as well as industry.

Key outcomes or other achievements:

This project takes a holistic approach to considering the effects of green roofs on air quality, with an emphasis on the emission and deposition of particulate matter and volatile organic compounds. These efforts have generated new knowledge about the effects of green roofs on HVAC filters. Our findings, that extensive green roofs may support a modest amount of ozone deposition and substantial CO2 uptake, without contributing negatively to isoprene or monoterpene emissions, set a baseline on which future designs might improve.  

Most of this project?s research is associated with a flagship roof located on a big box store in North Portland which includes paired white roof and green roof sections (Figure1).  By utilizing this site as a living laboratory, we were able to coordinate efforts across research questions and disciplines.  These efforts were informed by smaller scale pilot studies on our green roof testbeds at Portland State University as well as through experiments conducted in the lab for which we built specialized monitoring chambers. In collaboration with another NSF-funded S-STEM project on our campus, as well as through support from and REU supplement, we were able to engage classrooms of students with our work over the course of multiple years and summer bridge events.

Specific Objectives:

Particle deposition studies:

On our commercial roof field site, we sampled bulk deposition of particulate matter from 2018-2019. A PSU honors thesis student designed a sampling device that will collect roof particulate samples at known windspeed and direction. Runoff samples from both green and white portions of the roof were collected and analyzed for metal and nutrient content for approximately the same 2018-2019 period (Figure 2). Ongoing efforts will synthesize these different datasets to understand the fate of particulates being deposited. In 2020, an additional honors thesis investigated the relative concentration of particulates on green and white roof surfaces, concluding that deposition per surface area unit was similar across these surfaces, but that green roofs have the potential to capture more particles due to a greater leaf surface area per unit roof area. In addition to Na and Fe, which were ubiquitous, the deposited particulate matter analyzed in this study, as well as the bulk deposition study from the previous year, was primarily comprised of the following metals: Mg, Al, Zn, and Mn.

Ozone Deposition and HVAC Filter Studies 

We conducted modeling, field, and laboratory studies to investigate the impact of green roofs on local and indoor air quality. A pilot study on ozone deposition to green roof surfaces showed minimal reduction as a result of roof greening (ranging from 0.25 to 1.8 ?g/m3), but rates of deposition were also dependent on fetch length and vertical mixing as well as vegetation characteristics. In field studies, we deployed micrometeorological and weathering monitoring stations that allow us to make eddy flux calculations at the rooftop scale. With these tools, we determined the turbulent transport rate from the atmosphere to a building?s rooftop and the surrounding area. Our results indicate that urban greenery, including green roofs, emit substantially less CO2 than surrounding urban ?hard? surfaces, like parking lots, roadways, and other built infrastructure. In laboratory experiments, we have investigated the potential for rooftops to impact indoor air quality by affecting the nature of deposited particulate matter on building ventilation filters that treat outdoor air. These findings indicate a significantly different genome between filters with outdoor air intake near greenery vs. conventional rooftop surfaces (Figure 3). We also observed differences in emissions of VOCs as a function of rooftop type. These data imply the need for longer term studies to evaluate the implications of the surrounding surfaces near building outdoor air intake on indoor air quality.

Volatile emissions from green roof plants

We designed and constructed a laboratory setup to enable the control of variables relevant for testing of vegetation-air quality interactions. Our laboratory flux chamber setup, consists of two 6 L double-walled glass chambers, and enables the control of key plant and microbial environmental parameters, including temperature, relative humidity, light intensity levels, CO2 concentration levels, and air residence times (Figure 4). To enable simultaneous measures of plant performance and VOC emissions, a Thouris chamber apparatus is plumbed to a modified, high-resolution CO2/H2O monitor (Licor 6400), as well as a proton transfer reaction -time of flight- mass spectrometer that enables real-time measurement of the amount and type of volatile organic compounds entering or leaving the chambers (Ionicon, PTR-TOF1000). We report some of the first ever VOC profiles for different succulent species (Figure 5), including the first ever recording of the diurnal variation in VOC and CO2 fluxes from succulents. As a result of a GOALI supplement, we were further able to explore the effects of biochar on VOC emissions from green roof systems; this work is ongoing.
